Class TextFile

java.lang.Object
  TextFile

public class TextFile
extends java.lang.Object

A simple I/O class to help students read from or write to a text file. The I/O classes that come with Java are very flexible, but are difficult for beginners to learn. This class is a substitute that does most of the simple things you need to do in intro Java courses.

None of the methods from this class throw exceptions. When errors occur, they print error messages and abort the program.

For more details, see method descriptions below as well as example programs provided with this class.

Version:
1.4, June 2007
Author:
Margaret Lamb

Field Detail

INPUT

public static final boolean INPUT
Constant for use in the TextFile constructor, meaning that the file will be an input file for reading.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

KEYBOARD

public static final TextFile KEYBOARD
A TextFile object for reading user input from the keyboard ("standard input")

OUTPUT

public static final boolean OUTPUT
Constant for use in the TextFile constructor, meaning that the new file will be an output file for writing.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

SCREEN

public static final TextFile SCREEN
A TextFile object for writing to the computer screen ("standard output"). This provides the same functionality as System.out, but is included for completeness, and also contains formatted print and println methods for ints and doubles.

Constructor Detail

TextFile

public TextFile(boolean mode,
                java.lang.String fileName)
Creates a new TextFile object for reading from or writing to a file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error message if the file can't be opened or if you attempt to read from an input file which does not exist.

Parameters:
mode - indicates whether the new file will be an input file (for reading) or an output file (for writing). Use one of the constants TextFile.INPUT or TextFile.OUTPUT.
fileName - the name of the file -- may be an absolute name ("c:/Java/Assignment 1/inputfile.txt") or a simple name ("inputfile.txt"). Simple names will be found in the same folder as your program (.java) files.
Method Detail

abort

public static void abort(java.lang.String msg)
Aborts the program with an error message. Included here just because it's generally useful, both for I/O and other purposes.

Parameters:
msg - the message to print before ending the program execution

close

public void close()
Closes the file when you're done using it. It's important to remember to do this to free system resources associated with the file and to make sure any buffered characters really make it to the file. It's not necessary to close the special Keyboard or Screen files.

eof

public boolean eof()
Checks whether we've reached the end of the (input) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file.

Returns:
true if we've reached the end of the file

print

public void print(boolean b)
Writes a boolean value to the (output) file (as "true" or "false").

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
b - the boolean value to write

print

public void print(char c)
Writes a single character to the (output) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
c - the character to write

print

public void print(double d)
Writes a double number to the (output) file in the default format. Uses as many digits as required without leading or trailing zeros.

Examples:
          println(123.45) prints "123.45".
          println(11.0/7.0) prints "1.5714285714285714".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write.

print

public void print(double d,
                  int width)
Writes a double number to the (output) file using a specified minimum width. Always uses 6 digits after the decimal point, even if that includes trailing zeros. Decimal digits after 6 are rounded. Pads with spaces on the left, if necessary, to reach the minimum width.

Examples:
          println(123.45,12) prints " 123.450000".
          println(11.0/7.0,9) prints " 1.571429".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

print

public void print(double d,
                  int width,
                  int precision)
Writes a double number to the (output) file using a specified minimum width and precision. Always uses exactly the specified number of digits after the decimal point, rounding the rest. (If the precision is negative, prints zero digits after the decimal point.) Pads with spaces on the left, if necessary, to reach the minimum width. If you want to specify the precision but not a minimum width, use a width of 1.

Examples:
          println(1.5714,5,1) prints " 1.6".
          println(1.5714,15,2) prints " 1.57".
          println(1.5714,1,6) prints "1.571400".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

print

public void print(int i)
Writes an integer to the (output) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
i - the integer to write

print

public void print(int i,
                  int width)
Writes an integer to the (output) file, using a specified minimum width. If the integer has fewer than the specified number of digits, it is padded on the left with blanks. If the integer has more than the specified number of digits, the minimum width is disregarded and the full integer is printed.

Example:
          println(1234,5) will print " 12345"
          println(1234,3) will print "1234".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
i - the integer to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

print

public void print(java.lang.Object obj)
Writes an object to the (output) file. The printing format corresponds to the "toString" method of that object's type.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
obj - the object to write

print

public void print(java.lang.String s)
Writes a string to the (output) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
s - the string to write

print

public void print(java.lang.String s,
                  int width)
Writes a string to the (output) file, using a specified minimum width. If the string is shorter than the width, it is padded on the left with blanks.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
s - the string to write
width - the minimum width

println

public void println()
Writes an end-of-line character to the (output) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

println

public void println(boolean b)
Writes a boolean value to the (output) file (as "true" or "false"), followed by an end-of-line character.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
b - the boolean value to write

println

public void println(char c)
Writes a single character to the (output) file, followed by an end-of-line character.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
c - the character to write

println

public void println(double d)
Writes a double number to the (output) file in the default format, followed by an end-of-line character. Uses as many digits as required without leading or trailing zeros.

Examples:
          println(123.45) prints "123.45".
          println(11.0/7.0) prints "1.5714285714285714".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write.

println

public void println(double d,
                    int width)
Writes a double number to the (output) file using a specified minimum width, followed by an end-of-line character. Always uses 6 digits after the decimal point, even if that includes trailing zeros. Decimal digits after 6 are rounded. Pads with spaces on the left, if necessary, to reach the minimum width.

Examples:
          println(123.45,12) prints " 123.450000".
          println(11.0/7.0,9) prints " 1.571429".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

println

public void println(double d,
                    int width,
                    int precision)
Writes a double number to the (output) file using a specified minimum width and precision, followed by an end-of-line character. Always uses exactly the specified number of digits after the decimal point, rounding the rest. (If the precision is negative, prints zero digits after the decimal point.) Pads with spaces on the left, if necessary, to reach the minimum width. If you want to specify the precision but not a minimum width, use a width of 1.

Examples:
          println(123.45,9,3) prints " 123.450".
          println(11.0/7.0,3,1) prints " 1.6".
          println(11.0/7.0,1,2) prints "1.57".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
d - the number to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

println

public void println(int i)
Writes an integer to the (output) file, followed by an end-of-line character.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
i - the integer to write

println

public void println(int i,
                    int width)
Writes an integer to the (output) file, using a specified minimum width, followed by an end-of-line character. If the integer has fewer than the specified number of digits, it is padded on the left with blanks. If the integer has more than the specified number of digits, the minimum width is disregarded and the full integer is printed.

Example:
          println(1234,5) will print " 12345"
          println(1234,3) will print "1234".

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
i - the integer to write
width - the minimum number of output characters to write; the method will add spaces at the beginning if necessary to make this number of characters.

println

public void println(java.lang.Object obj)
Writes an object to the (output) file, followed by an end-of-line character. The printing format corresponds to the "toString" method of that object's type.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
obj - the object to write

println

public void println(java.lang.String s)
Writes a string to the (output file), followed by an end-of-line character.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
s - the string to write

println

public void println(java.lang.String s,
                    int width)
Writes a string to the (output) file, using a specified minimum width, followed by an end-of-line character. If the string is shorter than the width, it is padded on the left with blanks.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an input file.

Parameters:
s - the string to write
width - the minimum width

readChar

public char readChar()
Reads a single character from the (input) file. Does not skip whitespace characters.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file, or if we have already reached the end of the file.

Returns:
the character read from the file

readDouble

public double readDouble()
Reads a double from the (input) file. It skips any whitespace characters, reads the next "word" and converts it to a double.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file, if we have already reached the end of the file, or if the next word is not in legal double format

Returns:
the integer read from the file

readInt

public int readInt()
Reads an integer from the (input) file. It skips any whitespace characters, reads the next "word" and converts it to an integer.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file, if we have already reached the end of the file, or if the next word is not in legal integer format

Returns:
the integer read from the file

readLine

public java.lang.String readLine()
Reads the next line from the (input) file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file, or if we have already reached the end of the file.

Returns:
the line read from the file (minus the ending '\n')

readWord

public java.lang.String readWord()
Reads the next "word" from the (input) file. A word is a sequence of characters other than the "whitespace" characters (space, tab and newline). It will skip any initial whitespace and then read characters until it sees either a whitespace character or the end of the file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file, or if we have already reached the end of the file.

Returns:
the word read from the file

skipWhiteSpace

public void skipWhiteSpace()
Skips "white space" in the (input) file. White space characters are blanks, tabs and newlines. This method throws away white space characters from the input until it reaches either a non-white character or the end of the file. It's not an error to call this method when you're already at the end of the file.

Errors:
          Will abort with an error if this is an output file.
